text: The NF kappa B independent cis - acting sequences in HIV-1 LTR responsive to T-cell activation .
The rate of transcription initiation directed by the long terminal repeat ( LTR ) of HIV-1 increases in response to mitogenic stimuli of T cells .

Here we show that the response of the HIV-1 LTR may be governed by two independent sequences located 5 ' to the site of transcription initiation sequences that bind either <extra_id_0> NFAT-1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> or NF kappa B .

The rate of LTR - directed gene expression increased in response to treatment with either a phorbol ester or <extra_id_0> tumor necrosis factor alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> if either the <extra_id_0> NFAT-1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> or NF kappa B binding sites were deleted , but failed to respond to these mitogenic stimuli if both sequences were absent .

The HIV-1 mutant virus containing both NF kappa B and <extra_id_0> NFAT-1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> deletion was able to replicate although at a much decreased growth rate , while the deletion of <extra_id_0> NFAT-1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> alone increased the viral growth rate in Jurkat cells .
Neither deletion of NF kappa B nor deletion of <extra_id_0> NFAT-1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> decreased activation of viral replication by phorbol ester .
